support.p: rejected monument National Monuments Record of Wales (NPRN): 301072 Church of St Michael and All Angels
support.note: Described as sandstone...very fine-grained, homogenous, quartz dominated, mid-blue grey...the precise source of this lithology has not been established but it is similar to lithologies in walls local to the church (Edwards 2013, 311).
support.desc: There is a chi-ro cross carved on the top of the inscribed face.

layoutDesc.layout: Rhys (1907, 94-95) saw a potential fragmentary Ogham inscription on the right edge of the inscribed face, however more recent assesments have classified the marks as natural (Edwards 2013). The stone is inscribed with a Roman-letter inscription in two lines reading vertically downwards, justified to the bottom. The Roman-letter inscription is immediately below the cross.

handDesc.handNote: According to Macalister (1945, 373), the Latin inscription has been chiselled. Edwards (2013, 312) described the Roman-letter inscription as medium incised. The Roman-letter inscription is described as neatly but unevenly set out. Line 2 begins towards the end of line 1. There are several closely packed letters...the lettering...is in capitals with miniscule S. In line 1, the left diagonal of A is longer, extending beneath the I and the right diagonal is raised; C is large and angular; O is smaller and rises above the top of C; both N's lean towards the left; V is narrow; the top stroke of miniscule S projects over F which is cursive and has a curving upper horizontal, the second is conjoined with a small I; R has a closed loop and the tail curves upwards above the horizontal; M has widely spaced strokes which meet on the line; final I is horizontal and set above the line. In line 2, C is angular, the second I is smaller and the horizontal of T projects above it (Edwards 2013, 312).

history.provenance: On CISP, Macalister (1945, 372), notes that the left hand edge has been chipped, as though to destroy an Ogham. In the Welsh corpus, Rhys 1907 detected five notches, and Nash-Williams mentioned there might have been the vestiges of oghams; but seems to be damage to an edge/angle instead (according to Welsh Corpus).
In the church, standing against the wall in the north-east corner of the chancel (SH 5346 3785).

div.p: Ogham: No translation of the proposed Ogham inscription is offered

The first name in the Roman-letter inscription, Iaconus is most likely a derivative of OI. The most straightforward reading of the second name is, Firmin(i)us which was a popular Latin name seen elsewhere in Britain (Edwards 2013, 313). On the inscribed cross at the top of the stone, the Welsh Corpus comments that the 'monogram' chi-rho cross is one of two in Wales; the other is on Penmachno 4 (CN38) (Edwards 2013, 313).

The supposed Ogham inscription was suggested to correspond with the Roman-letter inscription which influenced the interpretation of it reading IACONI (Edwards 2013, 313). Rhys's (1907, 94-95) suggestion should not be considered credible given later investigations of the stone finding nothing but natural ridges and dips in its place (Edwards 2013, 313).
